Musicians;

Doug Wimbish: Bass, vocals, loops

Will Calhoun: Drums, percussion, loops

Vinx: Vocals, percussion, loops & samples


Jungle Funk is a trio composed of drummer Will Calhoun and bassist Doug Wimbish, both formerly of Living Colour, and Vinx, a backup percussionist for the likes of Sting and Peter Gabriel and a solo vocalist in his own right. 
Their debut, Jungle Funk, was recorded live in Austria in April 1998. 
The music contains elements of Living Colour-style hard funk, but it&#039;s updated for the 90s with drum programming, sampling, and other features imported from the world of jungle, drum &#039;n bass, and kindred DJ and dance genres. 
The band&#039;s press material asks, "How can three guys make that much sound??" Indeed, for a live recording, this is a technological powerhouse.

Jungle Funk relies heavily on technology, but they use it in subtle and musical ways. Some highlights include the digitally generated notes moving in unison with Vinx&#039;s scat vocal toward the end of "Ugly Face"; the intricate vocal layering heard on "September"; and the odd timbres that make up "Perculator" and "Prague City Lights." The fact that all these effects were pulled off at a live show makes them all the more impressive.

It&#039;s an interesting gambit: a funk/drum &#039;n bass/"DJ-inspired" project that is actually a band, rather than an anonymous, austere presence behind turntables and tape loops. One wonders whether "DJ-inspired" music can be successully melded to a 
more traditional live band concept. By making their debut a live recording, Jungle Funk intends to argue that it is possible.
There&#039;s only one way to find out: go see them live.
